No. 1286 dated 6th July 1940 about roads, though I agree that the roads here need improvement I do not share your opinion of their degree of badness. I know myself and have constantly been told by people from Iraq that the roads in the neighbourhood of Manamah are better than those on the outskirts of Baghdad and Basrah, they cannot of course be compared with roads in India. 2. Half of the actual receipts from vehicle taxes, not including driving licenses, is paid to the two Municipalities but when they undertake any big road job they are usually given a special subsidy by the Government, as,for an example, in the case of the Muharraq sea road extension and metalling the road near the Bank. Roads in Bahrain fall into two categories, those within the municipal boundaries of Manamah and Muharraq, which includes Hedd, which are dealt with by the municipalities and roads in other parts of the island which are made and kept up by the Government. ^n arrangement exists between the Government and the Bahrain Petroleum Company by which the company keeps in repair the road from Radm al Kawari (the bridge at the end of the date gardens) to ^wali as well as all the roads in the oil field and iiwali and refinery areas. 3. Last year approximately Rs 30,000/- was spent on town roads of which Rs 20,000/- was spent on widening roads inside the bazaar and Rs 10,000/- the cost of upkeep and construction of roads in the municipal area. The municipality has made use of the Bahrain Petroleum Company’s machines more than once and had been advised by the company’s experts but this method is expensive. This year it cost the municipality about Rs 3,000/- to grade and oil 5 miles of town roads and the result was not lasting. The metalled road from the Bank to the Customs cost approximately 4 annas per square foot. 4. The road from Manamah to Radm al Kawari is a bad one. It is narrow, twisting and has dangerous corners and innumerable old mosque sites projecting into the road which cannot be touched. I have tried for years, without success, to persuade the Shara to allow the removal of these mounds. This road needs constant repairs but if it is kept in order a good surface can be maintained for cars going at thirty miles an hour. Fifteen years ago, I believe, work was actually begun on a roadroad which was intended to go from Suq al Khamis through Bilad al Q,adim across the ford to Tubli and from there to the Rafaa road. The project was abandoned owing to lack of funds. This is a short cut but I think the construction of a causeway across the muddy creek would cost a great deal of money. I have examined this route several times lately. If this was contemplated the Budeya road to Senabus and thence across to Suk al Khamis could be used. There is another possible route, but considerably longer, which I have been across during the last few weeks, from Aali to Baar and onto the Budeya road near Makaba, but though this road would be of great use to the people of Budeya and other villages in that district it would increase the mileage between iiwali and Manamah. A third route, which already exists, is the new road branching off south of Radm al Kawari to the new bridge higher up the stream and then through date gardens to the road passing Behlah, which links the Manamah-Awali road with the Budeya road. This was built two or three years ago as a detour for donkey traffic but it could be improved and widened though the road crosses innumerable water channels and existing bridges would require rebuilding for heavy traffic. I think the sub-surface of part of this road, through the gardens, would be similar to that of the present Manamah - Radm al Kawari road as it is bordered by water channels but of these three alternatives the last is the most promising. 6. The Budeya road from Jedhafs, the Sehlah road and the road via Segeyya to Om mash’oon have all been built recently and are much used. physicalDescription.extent: The file is arranged in chronological order from the front to the rear of the file.

Foliation: the main foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 31; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. An additional foliation sequence is present in parallel between ff 3-28; these numbers are also written in pencil, but are not circled.

mods.abstract: The file contains correspondence related to roads in Bahrain. The correspondence is between the Adviser to the Bahrain Government (Charles Dalrymple Belgrave), the Political Agent, Bahrain, representatives of the Mesopotamia Persia Corporation Limited, the Manama Municipality, and Shaikh Hamad bin Isa Al Khalifah [Shaikh Ḥamad bin ‘Īsa Āl Khalīfah], ruler of Bahrain. The papers concern road maintenance and development, and complaints about the state of roads in the country, especially in relation to car tax revenues.Folios 29-30 are internal office notes.
